item.description:
Heroes vs Warlords


is the title of our new upcoming fantasy strategy game. Heroes vs Warlords will relaunch on KickStarter 2019.

Heroes vs Warlords is a fantasy strategy game set in the world of Pangea. Pangea is inhabited by clever Amazons, mighty Knights, wild Barbarians, and Neutrals. The Neutrals guard the treasures found in Pangea. The world of Pangea is largely unexplored. Vast lands, where no civilized soul has ever been before, are waiting for you.

Are you up to the challenge? Will your hero's army gain new riches for your empire? Will you crush the enemy hordes? Or will you fall victim to the monsters that are hidden in the various towers, ruins and mines scattered across the land.

Heroes vs Warlords is about the eternal struggle for supremacy. In this 1,2, or 3 player game you get the chance to see if you succeed. Will you be the ruler of Pangea?

Heroes vs warlords is inspired by the classic PC games of exploration and evolution of a hero and his army.

The game can be further expanded for a nearly unlimited amount of players with several upcoming expansions. A solitaire mode can be reached without extra cost just with a Kickstarter Stretchgoal.

—description from the publisher

Elemental Blast is a quick playing card game for 3-7 players. The players take on the role of Elemental Sorcerers using the elements to compete for elemental dominance, culminating when one Sorcerer achieves an Elemental Blast.

Elemental Blast is a light weight card game of strategic hand management. Starting with three cards each and using draw one/play one rules, the players utilize element cards to create effects to help themselves and hinder other players. Most harmful effects target the next player in turn order, but turn order can be reversed using certain elements. In addition, playing the same element that was just played creates a more powerful bonus effect that may affect additional players.

The goal is to collect five of the same element in your hand, referred to as an Elemental Blast. The first player to complete an Elemental Blast wins the game.

item.description:
An intriguing game of territory building and influence for 2-4 players

On distant Mars, beyond the reach of common Earth-dwellers, the Interspace Guilds vie for control of the Martian frontier. The Guilds orchestrate the movements and machinations of the nomadic colonists, necessary to securing critical resources and laying claim to a fresh region of Mars. The conductors of this activity are the Emissaries of the Guilds, freelance agents with a knack for subterfuge. As an Emissary, you are tasked with influencing the activities of colonists in a bid to fulfill a set of Guild contracts. The first such Emissary able to complete their contracts will secure control of the region in the name of their patron Guild.

In Emissary: Red Planet, players will explore a grid of location cards that represent a map of a region of Mars. Players will collect and spend resources to build up influence on the location cards by establishing new settlements for colonists. Each game will have a random set of three contract cards that determine the specific victory condition in play for that game, based on controlling certain types or arrangements of location cards. Players will compete through managing their hand of cards, modifying the cards in the map, and positioning their influence to secure control of the landscape.

Based on a video game of the 80s, the principle is clear: To win, Whacky Wit must eat all the dots (i.e. lower all the pegs), and the opponent's monsters must try to catch Whacky Wit and exhaust his three lives.

Whacky Wit is a two-player board game. One player plays the yellow Whacky Wit and the other player plays all four monster at once. The rules make this a balanced and fair thing. With slight gameplay modifications Whacky Wit can also be played with three or five players.

For whom is Whacky Wit suitable?

Whacky Wit is suitable for children from 7 years due to the intuitive rules.

How much time is needed to play?

A game lasts 10 to 25 minutes depending on the skill level and luck of the players.

The board game can be ordered at http://whacky-wit.com

item.description:
Primate Fear is set in the same world as Gigantoskop's Spank the Monkey and is compatible with that game and its expansions, but this time when you start monkeying around in a junkyard, you'll find it a much darker experience as this junkyard was built on an old haunted cemetery.

As in Spank the Monkey, players scrounge around trying to find junk to build towers and locate parts for reinforcements to make the towers stronger, but they're not trying to reach the monkey and spank it this time. Oh, no. On the contrary, they are trying to get as far away from it as possible because this monkey is not a mischievous nuisance but rather a reanimated zombie monstrosity of an ape. Once the players have stumbled over all the monkey parts and the monkey awakes, it will climb after the players, eating the brains of the ones it catches until only one player remains – the winner.

In game terms, each player starts with a hand of five cards. On a turn, a player draws 1-2 cards, then plays at most one Junk card to start or continue building his tower and at most one Reinforcement card to strengthen his highest Junk card. He can also play one or more Attack cards on opponents to try to demolish their towers, lowering them within reach of Frankenmonkey. Players can use Defense cards to try to ward off attacks, with the active player rolling a die to see whether an attack succeeds. If it does, that player's tower might further crumble as the junk collapses on top of other junk.

Each time a player uses a card with a monkey claw on it, a new part is added to Frankenmonkey on the assembly board; if the monkey is complete, then the claw raises the monkey up one level on the height board. At the end of each player's turn, the monkey (if still complete) rises one level, eliminating players at that same height.

Players can use Primate Fear cards with Spank the Monkey rules and vice versa, or they can combine the games, with the goal being to spank the monkey before anyone else while still having your brain intact.

Integrates with:


 Spank the Monkey

item.description:
From the publisher:

For the first round, each player draws a hand of “canon” answer cards, and one player is chosen to begin the game as “the Pharisee.” The Pharisee then presents a “creed” question card to the group, like:

“For Lent I am giving up_____.”
“What do good Christians wait until marriage for?”
“King Solomon needed so many women because he was over-compensating for _____.”
“Loving your neighbor as yourself includes _____.”
“When good Christians don't understand something in the Old Testament, they simply add Jesus and _____.”
“What is known to make the baby Jesus cry?”
 Each player passes one faced-down canon card to the Pharisee in response. The canon deck includes such biblical gems as:

The forbidden fruit (Genesis 3)
Noah's awkward sexual encounter with his son ( Genesis 9:22)
Levitical sex ban (Lev 18)
David carrying a warm sack of 200 foreskins (1 Sam 18:26-28)
A pair of she bears mauling a group of kindergarteners (2 Kings 2:23-25)
A naked boy running through Gethsemane (Mark 14:51-52)
Midgets in trees (Luke 19:1-10)
The voice of God knocking you off your ass, on your ass (Acts 9)
A slightly stoned Paul (Acts 14:19)
Making stupid life choices and blaming them on Php 4:13 (Php 4:13)
A roaring lion seeking whom he may devour (1 Peter 5:8)
After the players submit their canon cards, the Pharisee shuffles all of the answers, reads the responses out loud, and chooses his/her favorite card: the most biblically accurate, the most humorous, the card most likely to send the player to hell, or all of the above.

The winning player is given the Creed card from that round and the next player in line becomes the new Pharisee. The first player to collect ten Creed cards wins.

item.description:
In Concept, your goal is to guess words through the association of icons. A team of two players – neighbors at the table – choose a word or phrase that the other players need to guess. Acting together, this team places pieces judiciously on the available icons on the game board.

To get others to guess "milk", for example, the team might place the question mark icon (which signifies the main concept) on the liquid icon, then cubes of this color on the icons for "food/drink" and "white". For a more complicated concept, such as "Leonardo DiCaprio", the team can use the main concept and its matching cubes to clue players into the hidden phrase being an actor or director, while then using sub-concept icons and their matching cubes to gives clues to particular movies in which DiCaprio starred, such as Titanic or Inception.

The first player to discover the word or phrase receives 2 victory points, the team receives points as well, and the player who ends up with the most points wins.

item.description:
Game description from the publisher:

The once proud and strong Blue Moon City has been plunged into chaos. The Golden Dragon has fallen, the Holy Crystal of Psi has shattered, and the old King has drawn his last breath. Worse, Blue Moon, the creator of all things, has vanished and Blue Moon City is left without a ruler.

Now the three elemental dragons – the only divine creatures remaining in the world – guard the fragments of the Crystal. The two royal heirs, Prince Roland and Princess Elinor, vie for the crown. The peoples of Blue Moon City may not know whom to follow, but whoever can rally them and claim the throne will gain the power to restore the Holy Crystal of Psi and perhaps convince Blue Moon himself to return.

Prepare to battle for the throne and restore peace to the city in Blue Moon Legends, a collected version of Blue Moon, Reiner Knizia's classic card game for two players! In Blue Moon Legends, you will gather the allegiance of one of the peoples of Blue Moon City, then lead them in a series of fights against another people. By winning these fights, you aim to attract the fickle attentions of the elemental dragons and win your way to the throne of the city.

Players can either play the game straight out of the box with decks or strategically customize the perfect deck to take down their opponent. With hundreds of cards from which to choose, no two games will be the same. Blue Moon Legends contains all cards from award-winning designer Reiner Knizia's Blue Moon card game in a single box.

item.description:
Sagacity and speed are the watchwords in this game that's puzzling in more than one way!

In KHROMIX, players collect cards to score points, and the player with the most points wins — but how they collect cards is somewhat tricky.

At the start of play, shuffle the deck and deal the cards out evenly among the players; most cards have a color word on them (e.g., "red"), but the word is printed in a non-matching color, say blue. On a turn, a player reveals the top card from his deck and (in most cases) says either "Color!" or "Word!", asking for opponents to yell out either the color of the text or the word printed on the card. If the first opponent to answer yells out correctly, she keeps this card (and any cards already on the table) and places it in her score pile; if the first player is wrong, the current card stays in the center of the table and the wrong player places one previously scored card in the center, too.

Some cards have special functions, such as allowing the player who wins the card to peek at the top card of an opponent's deck. Other cards are multipliers and they double the points scored for cards claimed previously; to track this, you must keep cards in order as you claim them. Still other cards are "Mystery" cards, and the player who reveals a Mystery card should immediately ask any question at all, the more bizarre the better. The first opponent who offers any kind of coherent answer wins that card and any others on the table.

As soon as a player runs out of her stack of cards, the game ends and everyone tallies their points (mostly positive but sometimes negative), summing points from bottom to top and remembering to multiply cards accordingly. Whoever ends up with the highest score wins!

The dead it is said were buried with an obolos, placed in their mouths, so that once a dead person's shade reached the underworld of Hades, it would be able to pay Charon (the ferryman) for passage across the river Acheron. Legend has it that those without enough wealth, or whose friends refused to follow proper burial rites, were forced to wander the banks of the Acheron for all eternity...

2 player, blind bidding, trick taking game in which players are bidding for passage to the underworld.

item.description: Gramopoly is a Monopoly-style roll and move educational game about grammatical parts of speech. There are three levels of play (Beginner, Intermediate, and Advanced), and the object of the game is "to become the first player to buy each part of his sentence".

name.value: Phraze-It! The Game of Crazy Phrazes

item.description:
Phraze-It! is a game for the whole family. Players age 8 and up will love turning initials into crazy phrases.

It's easy. The judge rolls the 30-sided dice and players get three random letters. Turn over the timer and let your creativity loose, making each letter the first letter of a word in a 3-word phrase. Write your phrase...then say it aloud...with feeling! The judge draws a judgment card and determines points in multiple categories. And everyone gets a chance to be the judge!

You could get points for being first to finish...or last! You could get points for most unpronounceable phrase...or the shortest! Or maybe you had the saddest performance...or the funniest. Nobody knows what's on the judge's card until after the phrases are created.

You play in rounds. The last round can mean big bonuses. The winner is the player with the most points.

Each round is guaranteed to surprise, delight or make you laugh. After all, the sillier the phrase, the better!

Phraze-It! can be learned in minutes, played by young and old. Great for families, friends, and adults.

And it's all about letting your creativity run wild and having fun.

Source: www.lotsowattsgames.com

name.value: Stella Nova: Journey of the Magi

item.description:
Stella Nova: Journey of the Magi is a race to see which of the wise men (magi), who have seen a new star (stella nova), can be the first to safely reach the Christ child in Bethlehem with the three gifts of gold, frankincense and myrrh.

Magi ride camels along the caravan trails from the Far East to Bethlehem. Each roll represents one day in the journey. Magi must carry enough food and water (Supply Cards) to get to the next city or oasis. For each daily roll, the magi must turn in a Supply Card. If the magi run out of supply cards on the trail, then they must go back and replenish their supplies.

The magi must overcome hazards on the dangerous caravan trails as they cross over mountains and through deserts, such as: blinding sand storms, attacks by robber bands, fog and clouds that obscure the guiding star, and hidden assassin spies. These obstacles can be overcome with the right cards: Tent Cards for sand storms, Weapons Cards for robbers, Compass Cards for fog, and Secret Code Cards for spies. These Equipment Cards can be obtained at different cities on the trails in the North-- if one can answer a trivia question. The player can choose from two types of questions: History & Geography, or Biblical Scriptures. Young children can play without having to answer the questions.

So as well as a Race Game, Stella Nova is a Strategy Game where players must decide which is the most efficient path to take, and what resources and equipment to keep and what to leave behind.

Of course the magi must also obtain the three precious gifts of gold, frankincense and myrrh to give to the Christ child. These Gift Cards are only available a specific cities in the South.

Magi can capture a wild stallion at the oases and get a Wild Stallion Card. These cards can provide an advantage, such as racing ahead or jumping over other magi, or can give a disadvantage to an opponent, such as going back three spaces.

Stella Nova is a great Party Trivia game too. Players demonstrate their knowledge by answering questions on Biblical history and geography to obtain the needed Equipment and Gifts Cards.

Note: Stella Nova is an Educational Game for students, because it's historically and geographically accurate. The cities have their ancient names from the time of Christ. For example, Yathrib in Arabia is called Medina today. It was renamed by the Muslim prophet Mohamed in about 622 AD.

name.value: Guerra de Mitos II: Aztek and Greek

item.description:
Guerra De Mitos II is a card game set in a fantastic world where different mythologies coexist. It is a different, dynamic game designed to be able to build different decks with very distinct and varied strategies, and each installment increases both the number of available mythologies and the game possibilities.

The game contains 150 cards split between the Greeks and the Aztecs mythologies. Each mythology includes 2 pantheons (cards that define your game strategy) + 33 cards for the gods deck (which includes characters, events and resources) + 40 cards for the designs deck (actions, equipment and summonings).

Each player in War of the Myths II needs to build his own deck of at least 51 cards (1 pantheon / 20 gods / 30 designs) of his choice, and each installment increases the diversity of characters, actions and strategies you can use in order to achieve victory.

Each player has to bring into play the cards his oracles offer him and play actions from the designs deck both in the influence phase (where the gods plan from their pantheon) and in the confrontation phase (where the characters who decide to go to battle fight to decrease the opponent’s power) to obtain supremacy or consign the opponent to oblivion.

item.description: Ko-No-Ha (The Tree's Leaves) is a wooden dexterity game themed around a tree and its leaves. The game comes with a wooden tree stand, leaf-base and 30 wooden leaves of three different shapes (fan-shaped, diamond-shaped and spade-shaped) and three colours (red, green and yellow). Players take turns rolling a pair of special dice. One die has the three colours on it and each color appears twice. The other die has the following numbers on it: 1,1,1,2,2,3. After rolling both of these dice the player must combine the number and colour. The player must then place the total number of correspondingly coloured leaves on the leaf-base. The player can place the leaves in any fashion, so long as they do not fall from the tree-base. Once finished the player pass the dice to the next player (clock-wise order) and that person repeats the aforementioned steps. If during the leaf placement stage any of the leaves fall off the tree the player doing the placing loses the game. All players managing to complete all leaf placement stages successfully win the game. Alternatively, if all other players fail during the leaf placement stage, the remaining player wins.

Players take on the roles of Grandes in medieval Spain. The king's power is flagging, and these powerful lords are vying for control of the various regions. To that end, you draft caballeros (knights in the form of colored cubes) into your court and subsequently move them onto the board to help seize control of regions. After every third round, the regions are scored, and after the ninth round, the player with the most points is the winner.

In each of the nine rounds, you select one of your 13 power cards to determine turn order as well as the number of caballeros you get to move from the provinces (general supply) into your court (personal supply).

A turn then consists of selecting one of five action cards which allow variations to the rules and additional scoring opportunities in addition to determining how many caballeros to move from your court to one or more of the regions on the board (or into the castillo - a secretive tower). Normally, you may only place your caballeros into regions adjacent to the one containing the king pawn. The one hard and fast rule in El Grande is that nothing may move into or out of the king's region. One of the five action cards that is always available each round allows you to move the king to a new region. The other four action cards varying from round to round.

The goal is to have a caballero majority in as many regions (and the castillo) as possible during a scoring round. Following the scoring of the castillo, you place any cubes you had stashed there into the region you had secretly indicated on your region dial. Each region is then scored individually according to a table printed in that region. Two-point bonuses are awarded for having sole majority in the region containing your Grande (large cube) and in the region containing the king.

item.description:
Soccer City is a football turn-based board game that reproduces every possible action in a real football match.

The game is played in turns by running events, represented in different cards that are played during the game. Dribbling, fouls, shots on goal, tactics...Soccer City is a complete football simulator inspired in the early twentieth century, with a retro look and a stunning design by illustrator Jorge Consuegra.

The full game comes with:

- The Board, 40 width x 68 length (centimeter).
- The Teams, (2 teams, 11 players each). 
- The Referee Dice (1) 
- The Tactical Pads (2)
- The Score 
- 6 Card Decks, Total 165 cards: 

 Offensive Action Cards (25) 
 Defensive Action cards (25) 
 Shot-on-Goal cards (25) 
 Goalkeeper Save cards (25) 
 Ball playing cards (48) 
 External Factors (17)




The game is played in turns, in which attacker plays first and then turn shifts to defender. Each player has a set of cards consisting in Ball cards, Offensive cards and Defensive cards and Shot on goal cards.

Attacking turn consists of 4 sequential phases, and players may decide whether to play them or pass to the next:

1 – Ball Passing / Player advancing 
 2 - Attacking / Tactical Action 
 3 - Shot on goal 
 4 - Team repositioning

Once Attacking turn is over, Defensive turn begins, which in 2 phases: 
 1 - Defensive / Tactical Action
 2 - Team repositioning

item.description:
They're Coming is a zombie survival game. You must move your survivors through several locations to the rescue station while fighting off your opponent's zombies.

Depending on the version of the game, players have two modes of play. In the "Single Pack" or "Travel Edition" of the game, one player take on the role of the survivors and the other the zombies; in the "Standard" or "Two Pack" version, both players take turns being survivors and zombies in a round of play. Survivors draw from a survivor supply deck and must navigate locations (chosen by the opponent) that are infested with zombies (which are played from the opponent's zombie deck).

In the Standard game, the player who gets the most uninfected survivors to the rescue station wins. Non-standard games can be played by increasing the number of locations that survivors must pass through and/or by reducing the number of survivors to start the game.

Let's Play Two! Baseball Game is a free, print and play baseball game released by Hot Stove Games in 2002. The game is designed to replicate what Henry Waugh's Universal Baseball Association Game may have looked like from the book, "The Universal Baseball Association Inc. J. Henry Waugh Prop." by Robert Coover. This allows you to create your own baseball league where players grow old, become all-stars or simply fade away from the league. From rookie to retirement you follow their careers and act as commissioner and God of their universe just as Henry Waugh did in the book.

The game is played by rolling three six sided dice to simulate a baseball game. Batters can hit for power, strike out, walk, etc. based on their roll. The unique thing about this game is if you play a full season the rules have you "re-rate" players based on their seasonal performance to continue play to the next season. This way, you create a living, breathing baseball universe with your own champions, hall of famers, and heros!

item.description:
Based on the popular long running 1988-2000 and 2004-2005 Tele 5, RTL II, tm3 and currently RTLplus since 2016 German game show of the same name. (for which in turn was originally adapted from a short-lived 1986 U.S. daytime game show on ABC called Bruce Forsyth's Hot Streak) First, the players determine which set of cards to work with. Then it determines the starting player, for which they continue clockwise. The first player pulls on the clock and draws the top card from the deck. Then He/She submits to his/her right players and starts the clock. the player must then now decide on which of the two generic terms the he/she will use and announce them. He/She then list three terms matching the topic while stopping the clock. The hands of the clock displays the score, which is listed in the circular column under the name of the player. Then the timer switches to the next player. In the following four rounds, five and even six terms must be found in the same subject.

The bonus round is also somewhat different that the actual TV series. for which the active player can draw new cards for so long, until the clock expires. For each card completely played, the player gets a point. Cards can continued to be pulled out until the time expires. at the end of the round, the Player will receive one point for each completed card that has been played. The winner is the player whose total is after the bonus round is the winner.

Piles is played using a standard 52 card deck, by four players in teams of two. Team members are opposite each other. The dealer deals out 10 cards for each player, one by one; the remaining 12 cards are placed in the middle of the desk, arranged in a 4x3 rectangle called “Castle”. The player left to the dealer starts play placing one card on the Castle; the others will follow in clockwise order. The color (red or black) of the first card played by the opener assigns the color of each team for that game: e.g., if the opener chooses to play a 3 of Hearts, he and his partner will be the Reds, and the other team the Blacks. Goal of the Reds is to score points by capturing black cards, and vice versa for the Blacks. Cards are to be placed on the Castle, on top of those already on the desk, forming piles controlled by the card on top of it. Each card has an intrinsic value that follows the natural order, starting from the Ace (1) up to the King (13). In the Castle, each card can have from 2 up to 4 neighbors, i.e. cards adjacent either horizontally or vertically. The total value of a card on the Castle is equal to its intrinsic value increased by 1 for each neighbor of the same color and decreased by 1 for each of the opposite: e.g. a red 10 having 3 red and 1 black neighbors, will have a total value equal to the intrinsic value of a Queen.

Rules of the game:
1 - it's alway allowed to place on top of a card another card of the same color
2- a card of the opposite color can be placed, changing the control of the pile, if the card to be placed has an intrinsic value higher than the total value of the card on top of that pile
3- a player can pass the turn. In that case, the opponent at his left will pick at random one of his cards. That card will be added to the piles picked up at the end of the game, possibly contributing to the score.

End of the game and scoring:
A game is over after 10 turns, when the players run out of cards. Each team picks up the piles topped by the cards of their color: all the cards of the opposite color inside the controlled piles are captured and used for the final score. In the final scoring, an Ace is worth 9 points, a King 4, a Queen 3, a Jack 2 and the remaing cards 1 point each. The Red team will sum up the values of the captured black cards, and the other way around for the Blacks.

Two players game:
The game can also be played by two players, under the same rules. In that case, when the two players run out of the first 10 cards, the dealer will deal out the remaing and the game will go on as usual.

Zombie Solitaire is like regular Klondike solitaire with one big difference: you get to save survivors and destroy Zombies!!!

Components:
Zombie Solitaire requires [2] decks of regular playing cards (including one “joker”), One deck will be used for the [52] cards and [1] joker. The other deck will supply the [7] zombies "the logo side of the cards" and four sets of A thru 6 for the [4] ammo boxes with 6 shots each.

You could use 4d6 instead of the four sets of A thru 6 for the ammo.

COMPONENTS:
Two normal decks of cards
• [1] 52 card deck for basic game play.
• [1] Joker, which represents you!
• [1] second 52 CARD deck, from which 31 cards are needed. These cards represent zombies that must be destroyed and ammo for your gun.
• [4] six-sided dice, representing a supply of ammunition for your gun

Zombie Solitaire can also be played using a specialized PnP version “Zombie deck”. 
PnP cards
• [4] Ace: a Safe House
• [4] King: Grandpa – the only character willing to sacrifice himself for his family
• [4] Queen: Grandma
• [4] Jack: Dad
• [4] 10: Mom
• [4] 9: the children and their friends
• [4] 8: the children and their friends
• [4] 7: the children and their friends
• [4] 6: the children and their friends
• [4] 5: the children and their friends
• [4] 4: the children and their friends
• [4] 3: the children and their friends
• [4] 2: the children and their friends
• [1] Joker: You, the armed and dangerous hero
• [7] Zombies - Cards from the second deck (logo side only)
• 4D6 die: ammo box (6 rounds each)

Setup:
Zombie Solitaire is set up like regular “Klondike” solitaire with 7 stacks, four collection zones for aces, and a draw pile – all from a single deck of cards. In addition, 10 cards from a second deck are set, faced down, in a pile to the right of the 7 stacks. The joker is placed below the zombie pile, with the [4] dice off to the side.
• Draw pile: crowd of survivors from the zombie apocalypse
• 7 stacks: temporary shelters to which some of the survivors have fled and others may follow. Cards that are face-down are temporarily hidden from view; when they are turned over, they can be spotted by the zombies
• 10-card pile (from second deck): zombie horde 
• Collection zones: areas in which safe houses may be established

Game Play:
The game is played like regular Klondike solitaire, with the usual options – moving cards from stack to stack, turning cards over when they become open, pulling the aces out and setting cards on top of them as appropriate – until the first card is drawn from the deck. That’s when the zombies finally arrive – and all bets are off!

In Zombie Solitaire, only one survivor card – the top card of the deck – is drawn each time.
Play the game as normal, but with the following adjustments:
• You do not have to play a survivor card that you have drawn from the draw pile even if you have an available play. It is always your choice whether or not to play a card.
• You cannot play a survivor card on top of a zombie card.
• You cannot move any card (or stack) that is under attack from a zombie and you cannot move any card (or stack) onto a stack that is under attack from a zombie – until the zombie is destroyed
• You do not come under attack for drawing an ace from the survivor draw pile (or from one of the stacks) and setting it up as a safe house and you do not come under attack for moving a survivor to a safe house. 
• You can move a king (and its stack) to an empty space on the board without coming under attack as long as there is no zombie on the king's stack. But if you move a king from the draw pile to the board, it will come under attack . 
 You do not come under attack when a survivor moves from stack to stack.
 When you draw the last card from the draw deck and flip the deck over, this causes a zombie to attack the oldest survivor at the bottom of a stack.
 
 When a second zombie attacks a stack the lowest card on the stack is eaten but that survivor destroys both of the zombies.

Zombie threat:
Individual zombies are not a threat to the survivors. They are endangered only when two zombies attack at the same time. When a second zombie card is added to a temporary shelter stack, the bottom survivor card is removed from the game (where it will contribute no victory points to the player’s total). The attack will also destroy one of the zombies, whose card is returned to the zombie horde.

Victory: 
The game is over when you no longer have any available moves, no kings to sacrifice and no ammunition. Count up the number of Safe Houses you established and the number of survivors who made it to a Safe House. You get [1] victory point for each.
A perfect score is 52.

item.description:
Rising Glory is the fourth game GMT Games is producing as part of their strategic friendship/partnership with Victory Point Games, and the 2nd from their Napoleonic 20 series (Fading Glory was the first). The idea for this and future volumes is that they will take multiple existing games from the VPG Napeoleonic 20 series, add an as-yet-unpublished game to the mix, and create a GMT boxed game with 3-4 games in the box, using larger (3/4") counters and mounted maps.

The Napoleonic 20 series from Victory Point Games are lower complexity wargames which use a common system originally created by veteran designer Joe Miranda, and further refined by developers Alan Emrich and Lance McMillan. The system’s name is derived from the fact that there are generally just 20 or fewer pieces in play on the map at one time (that's 20 pieces total, for both sides). The system is easy to learn and fast-playing, creating a tense, dramatic and challenging situation on the game board where higher echelon troop formations (generally corps) vie for position and dominance. The series features twelve pages of Standard rules, four pages of Optional rules, and one-to-two pages of Exclusive rules for each title.

A hallmark feature of the Napoleonic 20 series is the use of narrative random event cards to help “tell the story” unique to each battle or small campaign. This “friction of war” element, combined with the operational-level maneuver, intense combat, and even periods of inactivity as armies pause to rest and reorganize, provides a thrilling battle full of unexpected twists and reversals of fortune. Morale plays a vital role as both sides can ‘spend’ this precious resource to force march their units, help rally stragglers, or commit reserves to key combats. But look out… when a side’s morale is reduced to zero, it has lost the game! The games also features simple optional rules for limited intelligence/Fog-of-War, the important shaping effects of leadership, and the gradual erosion of troop effectiveness due to fatigue.

The Rising Glory multi-pack features one game each from Alan Emrich and Lance McMillan, and two designs by Kim Meints.

Austerlitz 20(the “Battle of the Three Emperors;” Napoleon vs. Kutuzov, 1805)
Jena 20, 2nd edition (Napoleon vs. the Brunswick & Hohenloe, 1806)
 Eylau 20 (Napoleon vs. Bennigsen, 1807)
Wagram 20 (Napoleon vs. Archduke Charles, 1809)

Game Components:

Four 17” x 22” mounted maps ( 2 boards, backprinted)
Approximately 150 3/4" Counters (thick, with Rounded corners, like No Retreat)
48 Event cards (12 for each game)
One 16-page Standard Rules booklet
One 16-page Exclusive Rules playbook
Two Player Aid charts

Individual Games designed by Alan Emrich, Lance McMillan, and Kim Meints

On February 9, 2015, GMT Games deleted this game from their P500 list and gave it back to Victory Point Games.

From the box: "471 ans d'histoire de l'Acadie. Jeu éducatif pour tous les âges. 471 questions et réponses."

This trivia game for 2 to 4 players was published in celebration of the First World Acadian Congress held in South-East New Brunswick, Canada in 1994. Beginning at the commemorative Acadian church at Grand Pré, Nova Scotia, players roll a d6 and move their tokens along four tracks on a map taking them through the main Acadian settlement areas in North Eastern North America. Depending on the colour of the space a player lands on, she must answer correctly a trivia question about one of three themes in Acadian history: blue for dates, white for people and red for places. When falling on a yellow space, players re-roll. The first player to reach South Eastern New Brunswick, where the first "Retrouvailles" took place in 1994, wins.

The year is 1840 and America’s first mining boom is about to strike in the remote wilderness of Michigan's Upper Peninsula. Take on the role of a mining company and compete for copper by casting miners and machines into what was known as the underground lottery. As the industry grows, so do the communities surrounding your mines. But every attempt to wrest copper from the ground hangs the fortunes of your company, and the lives of your miners, in the balance.

In Copper Country, each player takes on the role of a unique mining company and competes to produce the most copper before it's all gone! To produce copper, players hire miners to work mine sites. Your miner's productivity is measured in shifts. Each shift, you reveal one card from the top of the production deck, then choose an outcome by playing capital card resources from your hand, placing your miner at risk, or both!

Stake your claim by building company houses to increase your miners' loyalty and safety. Expand your mining empire by building shaft houses and hoist houses to increase your copper production.

When a player produces copper, the byproduct — poor rock — is removed from the industry track and dumped onto the mine site, reducing shifts nearby for all players. As players remove more poor rock from the industry track, local businesses open their doors, historical events occur, and Copper Country enters new eras of production. The game ends when the last poor rock is dumped onto a mine site, depleting Copper Country's mineral wealth. The winner is the player who has produced the most copper!

item.description:
A party game of Silver Linings.
Laugh with friends as you discover hope in the bleakest situations your twisted minds can invent. Inspired by research into how positive thinking (and a sense of humor) promotes mental health, The Upside is a lighthearted and uplifting way to spend 30 minutes realizing that you might not have it so bad after all.

Every round starts with a little chaos and mayhem. Players roll the disaster dice to provide the who, what and how of each round's terrible situation. The dice produce combinations like "Global medical disaster" or "Personal Financial Adversity"

Then players flip over an inspiration card where Mr. Upside suggests how to make the situation even worse. All of a sudden the story could become "Global Medical Disaster caused by Diabolical Mermaids" which is so much more awesome.

Then players race to find the silver lining by coming up with the most creative positive spin to life's little disasters before time runs out. Responses get one point for being unique and one point for being the best of the round. Play continues until a player has 13 positivity points- whereupon he or she is dubbed the quintessential Mr. Upside.

item.description:
Strategic multi-player card game featuring an original, colour-coded, 80 card, tarot based deck. Cards are imbued with "special powers" to help players formulate their plans to dominate gameplay.

A hand of seven (or eight) cards is dealt to each player. The first player to play all cards in his/her hand, "goes out" and wins the hand with zero Points. The other players count the point value of the cards they are still holding, and record them. A Game consists of five hands. Lowest score wins.

Reviving the historic gaming tradition of the Tarot, Tarocchi or Tarok that originated in Europe during the 15th Century... Alliances, Accusations, Attacks, Arguments, Bluffing, Banter, Control, Challenges and Cheating are the ABC's of OCCO. Simple to Learn, Challenging to Master, Fun for ALL AGES!

Tiamat, the sea God of Chaos, is displeased. Fishermen and sailors used to pay homage to Taimat in turn for fair seas and little trouble. However, the sailors have grown comfortable and neglected to respect Tiamat. In an effort to regain the control she once had, Tiamat has entrapped random sailors in her ever-changing seas of chaos. Forcing these sailors to turn to a life of piracy, they will have to navigate ever changing seas, explore ocean, plunder treasure and fight each other to survive! Only the most successful and rich sailor turned pirate will be set free from her chaotic world.

Players each start with a simple vessel and gradually gain stats to build their vessel in different categories to develop their own strategy to win. Players can upgrade their speed, hull size, defense, and attack. The more treasure you collect, you advance your Pirate Rating. The first player to a Pirate Rating of five, triggers game end. The winner is the player with the highest value of treasure.

The game board is modular. The modular hexagonal tiles consist of different islands and treasure that need to be discovered to come into play. There are islands that contain treasure, repair docks, Merchant ports where you can buy Merchant cards to help you on your travels, or empty islands that complicate your sailing. There are also open ocean tiles and whirlpools. Whirlpools also give you cards, of which most have negative effects on your ship or others. The games starts with everyone on the main island. Once a player starts sailing, they discover the modular game tiles as them move. The tiles are pulled at random from a shuffled deck to keep the gameboard different for every game.

While a player navigates the treacherous waters, they are on the lookout for treasure. Once a player finds their treasure, they will plunder it from an island, and bring it back to the starting Island in which they will bury the treasure for safe keeping.

Players use number combinations and strategy to get rid of all their cards to win the game. The two face up active cards are added, subtracted, multiplied or divided to create "target numbers". At each turn players put down one or more number cards that add up to (or Equal) those target numbers.

There are also 8 different Action Cards that add variety, strategy, and surprises to the game. The game can last under 10 minutes if a player can get rid of the cards in just a few turns, or it can run up to about 20 minutes.

Players get better, faster and more confident with numbers just by playing Equals. This makes Equals perfect for families with children and classroom teachers.

This New edition of the “Settlers of Catan – Board Game” features a six piece reversible board allowing for more replay value than the previous Gallery Edition.

Get together with friends or family. Learn to play in about 15 minutes. Then enjoy countless hours of fast-paced fun!

Begin a quest to settle the island of Catan! Guide your brave settlers to victory by using clever trading and shrewd development. Use resources – grain, wool, ore, lumber, and brick – to build roads, settlements, cities and key cultural milestones. Get resources by rolling the dice or by trading with other players.

But beware! You never know when someone will block your way or if the robber will strike and steal your hard-earned goods! Are you the best trader, builder, or settler? Will you master Catan?

item.description:
Among the many reasons that Oaxaca (pronounced wah-HA-kah) is well known are its exquisite handicrafts. Drawing upon generations of tradition, as well as Oaxaca’s vast quantities of raw materials, entire families within this state in Southern Mexico dedicate their lives to perfecting their craft. You are a family of skilled Oaxacan handicraftsmen preparing to sell your artisan wares to eager tourists at a bustling tianguis (a large, outdoor market) within Oaxaca City. Can you lead your family to a distinguished position with your exquisite craftsmanship, or are your crafts common for the culture?

GOAL
Specialize in specific craft types to create more desirable handicrafts. The player who has the most valuable collection of crafts in their Market Stall at the end of the final round is the winner.

item.description:
LOCAL HERO! 
Devious political strategy in a box - can you stop people opening the lid on it? Grass roots politics with all the mud thrown in!

CITY HALL PROTEST! New fast paced board game based in a fictional local community, but maybe something like yours! You run your own protest group NO! NEVER! ACTION! NOW! STOP! OR NIMBY! Be the first to get 20 protest points and become a LOCAL HERO! by making your community a better place!

Based in a fictional local community, You lead your own protest group and each turn try to run the City! Each player competes to fill City Hall with their supporters and stay in control of the mob (the other players).

The player who runs the City Hall is City Leader! There can only ever be one Leader, so staying in control of the City means learning the rules and using them to your advantage! If no one player dominates City Hall then deals have to be done and undone between players about who stays in power.

Each turn players move around the board along the green belt as they protest to improve their city and have to make decisions about which other players they support. Decisions are made on the basis of facts, feelings and trust, reasoned argument or power play and determined by the number of cards players have in City Hall.

Each turn can change the number of cards a player has and so alter their influence. Players have to manoeuvre themselves between seeking power and staying true to their cause until one player has gained 20 protest points and becomes the LOCAL HERO! Points are gained by taking control of the City, time served as Leader and from doing deals with other players to get their support.

This leads to a fast paced game, players are constantly changing sides, working out who best to support, and not being corrupt. It is an exhausting game of wit, strategy, coercion and survival that brings out the best and the worst in participants!

In the end you don't just win you make the World a better place! and had an exciting evenings entertainment with family and friends.

Object: Be the first player to put all of their spots on the worms.

Each player is given a number of spots (depending on the number of players). Players take turns spinning a spinner that indicates a color of worm. That player than places one of their spots on the indicated worms. The player that runs out of spots first wins.

This is a children's game produced in 1970 by Whitman. For kids ages 4 to 8.

item.description:
It's the dawn of the Livonian Crusade, and Estonia is being conquered by several nations. The Danish forces of Valdemar the Great are arriving from the West. The Crusaders, led by Bishop Albert, are crossing the borders from the South. Vsevolod, Prince of Novgorod, is attacking from the East. There's only one hope for Estonians: Lembitu, the leader, who is brave enough to fight against all the conquerors.

Lembitu is a co-operative board game inspired by the events of the Livonian Crusade in Estonia. Players are in the role of generals, fighting against conquerers and initiating rebellions. Actions can be used for movement, fighting or uprisings — but as each player has only a limited number of actions, they must plan carefully. The direction and speed of enemy movement is decided by dice, but the enemy's ultimate goal is to reach Paide. If they don't reach it within a fixed amount of turns, the players win.

In an ancient world forgotten by time, enormous titans terrorize the land. Five tribes have been fleeing from the titans for centuries, but things are about to change. Growing city-states pledge to end the reign of terror, determined to take on the titans and make the world a safer place for all. Each city-state competes to attract the tribes, eager for the strength of the combined peoples, who are now leaving behind old traditions with the hope that the titans can be defeated once and for all.

In The Ancient World, players compete to grow the largest and most influential city-state by managing citizens, treasury, and military and by defeating titans. Players take turns sending citizens to take special actions or using military cards to attack titans. One of the actions a citizen can perform is to build Empire cards, which give more citizens, money, and abilities.

A city-state's influence in the world is measured by sets of tribe banners that it owns. Each Empire card has one or more tribe banners, and tribe banners can also be gained by defeating titans. Players gain victory points (VPs) for sets of tribe banners. After six rounds, the player with the most VPs from sets of tribe banners wins.

item.description: Many are called but few are chosen! Who will stand and fight against the forces of darkness? Fear not, for you have been chosen by the Host of Heaven to die to yourself so others may live. In this exciting new game players are challenged to live out an ancient principle that you die to gain, and you live to die. Filled with unusual scenarios and life changing scriptures, this game turns spirituality into practicality! Is the game about luck, or is it fate, you be the judge as you become a missionary in your own backyard. Your task is to fight to win lost souls, and redeem your poverty stricken neighborhood back into a plush thriving community. As players travel around the board using dice, each person will encounter 4 types of spaces: natural, spiritual, witness, and proprty spaces. Each player's goal is to equire the most souls, buy property, and build an underground church. The player with 6 souls on one property wins and game play stops. However, achievements will be divided up amongst players (most property, most money, most souls, most property). Each space corresponds with a card. Natural cards have consequences to gain money, lose turns, etc. Spirtural cards: players read inspiring passages, play act, etc. Witness cards are the only cards players can win souls with. Players can win or lose souls depending on scenior. So put on the whole armor of God as this game will put your skills to the test! The table is set, everything’s unwrapped, and it’s game time, are you ready to die to live?

Starstead, a card-drafting/set-collection card game for 2-3 players, employs a novel card-drafting mechanic that allows players to Explore, Claim and then Settle in star systems of different types and sizes. Once enough of a type have been Settled, players can Utilize each system’s special ability to further their positions, scoring more points and expanding their empire!
Mechanically, players will be collecting sets of System cards and playing them in front of them. A player’s final score is based on the System type of which a player controls the lowest value, so an even balance of development is key. However if a player settles more than a critical value of a System type, he/she can utilize that type’s ability every turn for the rest of the game!

item.description:
A fast-pace game of memorizing words and being bossed around by a deck of cards! Topsy Turvy forces you to remember a sequence of words created by the players while trying to draw cards following their simple yet distracting instructions.

Will you master the art of memorization? Or will you break the sequence and turned Topsy Turvy!

Topsy Turvy is a sequence memory game that challenges players in their skill of memory. Players decide who goes first, then that player decides on the first word of the sequence and draws a card. This card determines which player gets the next turn. That players says the sequence, adds a word, and draws a card.

Sometimes, a card does not simply determines the next player, though, but tries to throw off the players' train of though, such as the "Erase" card that deletes any word of the current player's choice.

St. George and the Dragon is played on a round board shaped like a wheel with 14 spokes, with a pattern of points on those lines starting from its center and radiating out to the edge of the board. Longitudinal lines are also drawn connecting the points. The central circle is green and is called the Dragon’s Lair. At four equidistant locations on the outer circle, an additional three points (connected by lines to each other and to three points on the board’s outer edge) form Knight’s Castles, one each named for St. George, St. Patrick, St. Andrew, and St. David. The Dragon’s lone piece begins the game on the Dragon’s Lair; the Knights’ three pieces each begin on the points of the Knight’s Castle.

Beginning with the Knights and ending with the Dragon, players take turns rolling a die and moving according to the results. The player will move any one of their pieces the exact number of points rolled on the die, in any combination of directions, so long as the lines between points are followed and points are not crossed or landed on a second time. Pieces cannot move to or jump over occupied points, except when the Dragon captures a Knight. Dragons move in the same fashion as Knights, but when their move ends on an occupied point, that Knight is removed from play. The Dragon may win the game by taking two of each Knight’s pieces. Knights may not capture or slay the Dragon, but may win by reaching the Dragon’s Lair central point with two of their pieces. The first Knight to do so wins the game. A Knight may not pass over the Dragon’s Lair as part of a move; they must land there only on the end of their move. Having landed on the board’s central point, the Knight is then removed from play and set behind his Castle to keep score.

The game can be played by two, three, four, or five players. For five players, one each plays a Knight and one the Dragon. For four players the game is the same but St. Patrick’s Knights are not used. For three players, one player takes the Knights of St. Andrew and St. George, one player takes St. David and St. Patrick, and one the Dragon. For two players, one will play all four Knights and the other the Dragon.

St. George and the Dragon takes its inspiration from the old tale of the same name.

As HexDame is a hexagonal adaptation of International Checkers, Pskov Checkers (or Pskovskie Shashki) is a Checkers Family game adapted to a hexagonal board, in this case probably Shashki, though no inventor or date of creation is currently known.

Pskov Checkers can be played on one of two boards, both of them regular hexagons comprised of hexagonal cells. The smaller board consists of 37 cells, four to each side of the larger hexagon. The larger board consists of 61 cells, five to each of the larger hexagon’s sides. Both boards are set between two players with a point closest to each player. On the smaller board, each player has 13 pieces, arranged on every cell of their half of the board, with a row of vacant cells in the middle. Likewise on the larger board, but with 24 pieces per player.

Other than the varying boards and arrangement of pieces, the difference between Pskov and Shashki is in the promotion of pieces; in Pskov Checkers, pieces can only be promoted on the farthest corner cell, closest to the opponent, rather than the furthest row as in Hexdame.

5 Kingdoms is a card/tile laying game where the object of the game is to score the most points by controlling a combination of five territories called realms. Players draw, manage, and place land cards in patterns according to their type. In addition to placing land cards players must also place five kingdom tokens on the land cards in order to create point scoring realms.

There are six different land cards: deserts, forests, hills, lakes, mountains, and swamps. Each land type is placed in a particular pattern and scored in its own fashion. Lakes are the only land cards that cannot be claimed by a kingdom token to score points.

In basic gameplay the kingdom tokens do not have any special value causing only the claimed land cards to be scored at the games end. During advanced play each of the players five kingdom tokens has a special ability that can effect kingdom token and land card placement or scoring. The five advanced kingdoms are cloud, fire, gold, iron, and water.

5 Kindgoms does not require a playing board or score counter and is limited only by the flat surface it is played on.

Contents:

96 tile cards (16 cards of each land type)
25 double sided kingdom tokens

item.description:
Galassia is a space racing game of the 80s in which each player must be able to build a path from Earth to the planets that were randomly assigned at the beginning of the game, through the placement of the space lanes tiles.

Each player also tries to hinder other players in their purpose. They also have strategic cards at their disposal, which can help a player get past space lanes closed by his opponents.

The spacecraft, which can be moved by all the players, move from Earth to the planets with the spinner.

Players get points for arriving at the planets, with players who arrive earliet getting more points. The game ends when everyone has reached their destination; the player with the most points wins.

name.value: Mighty Heroes and the Monster Zone

item.description:
Mighty Heroes and the Monster Zone (MHMZ) is a game of strategy and chance utilizing cards, dice, and miniatures. Each player controls a faction (Spies, Ninjas, Robots, or Pirates) consisting of a faction deck of 8+ cards, a miniature representing a Hero, and a display tile. They will advance up the game board with their Hero by attacking fellow players, slipping by uncontested, or by battling monsters. As they move up the board they are hindered and helped by random Special FX cards. Each faction has a unique special ability to aid in their advance. Heroes will also level up as they make progress. The first Hero to make it into the wormhole at the top of the board wins.

Basic Premise: An evil mad scientist has merged our universe with that of the Monster Zone. As is becomes more and more corrupted a wormhole to an alternate dimension opens and all the Heroes desperately attempt to make it through to safety before it closes.

Heroes' Tale: The Corrupted Forest is a fusion of Tabletop RPG and card games. It uses a 20-sided dice system along with playing cards. The game can have has many players as the Game Master wants. One player plays as the Game Master, which plans and controls the world the Heroes live in. The rest play as Heroes’ and try to survive in the world the Game Master creates.

ï»¿The Heroes can completely customize their own characters through diverse vendor decks, which they use to purchase gear and abilities from. The Game Master may also place down a vendor deck for the Heroes to buy from.â€‹

The Game Master makes his own campaign deck filled with Environment Cards, Creature Cards, and Ally Cards. He uses this deck to create a world for the Heroes to live and fight in. The more cards you have as a game master the better off you are at making any kind of scenario and encounter you would like.

item.description:
The Red Queen is a card game pitting a team of 2 to 5 players against the infamous Queen of Hearts, a character as unpredictable as Lewis Caroll described in Alice's Adventures in Wonderland. Using deduction to work out how best to advance their plans, the team must assemble an army of soldiers to challenge the Red Queen.

In The Red Queen, the player cards are facing outwards in such a manner that all players except the one holding them will know what they are. Each round players will be able to give clues to one another to lift part of the mystery surrounding the pool of cards they collectively possess, build their army, or use special roles actions to help them in this endeavour.

... meanwhile the evil Red Queen will continually interfere with the team using a set of treacherous actions in the hope to make them lose 'heart', literraly, the currency representing the team's morale in the game. Her own army will also grow throughout the game, putting the team under pressure to raise their own as efficiently as possible.

The game features a strong thematic element and role cards based on characters directly inspired by Lewis Caroll's work. Alice herself takes on a key role too, unsurprisingly, but as an outsider will be of equal support to both sides and it is up to the players to make the most of her abilities.

In Fühlzwerge, players need to put fingers on their eyes in order to find the right items fast.

To set up the game, place all twenty cardboard tokens into the bag; these tokens are shaped to resemble the items depicted on them: an elephant, a ship, a wheel, a tree, and so on. Each player receives an equal number of cards from the deck, with each card showing one of these twenty items. The youngest player takes the dwarf die.

When the game starts, everyone but the youngest player shoves one hand into the bag at the same time and tries to grab items depicted on the cards in front of them. If a player draws a token matching such a card, great! Place the item on that card. If he instead draws a token matching a card in front of another player, well, he just helped that player get one step closer to victory as he must place the token of the card anyway. The player with the die rolls it repeatedly, possibly needing to jump up then sit back down, possibly needing to switch hands. As soon as she rolls her second dwarf, she passes the die to the closest player clockwise, who must then start rolling while she tries to fish tokens from the bag.

As soon as someone has tokens on all of her cards, she wins the game! (Players can also play without the die, with everyone fishing for tokens at the same time.)

Odysseo is a chance and strategy game. The goal is to move your checkers from a starting point to one of the available exits (the opponents' starting points).

During your turn, rolls the dice, then moves one of your checker by the corresponding number of cases. Whenever possible introduce a new checker on the board.
Checkers movement is limited by simple rules: 1) moving back and forth during the same turn is also prohibited; 2) moving through other checkers is not permitted; 3) finishing the movement on an opponent's checkers removes it from the game; 4) finishing the movement on a blue case removes your checker from the game.
Also, having one of your checkers being removed while standing on one of the white cases surrounding your starting point allows you to recover the removed checker.

The game ends when there is only one player with checkers left on the board and scoring is done as such: 1) saved checkers: 2pts each; 2) checkers on the board: 1 pt each; 3) removed checkers: 0 pt each.

The length of the game can be shortened by starting with fewer checkers.

War has erupted across the Imperium! Four spacefaring races struggle for supremacy, launching fleets of starships across the galaxy to battle for control of the most prosperous systems. Only one race will successfully Expand, Explore, Exploit and Exterminate their way to victory!

Pocket Imperium is a 4X microgame. Players will need to use the opportunities to expand, explore, exploit and exterminate to their best advantage. The timing of when to build fleets, when to explore the stars, and when to invade systems controlled by opponents will be crucial in their quest to rule the Imperium.

What's more, in a crowded galaxy, players must choose wisely when to make alliances to bring down powerful enemies — and when to break those pacts to critically weaken their former allies!

Carcassonne: South Seas is the first game of a new series titled "Carcassonne Around the World".

item.description:
Reaction game for large groups.

All players, except the dealer, are tapping on the table with their fingers. If the dealer calls a command, which can be a color or symbol, all players should lay their hand on the right card as soon as possible. But beware, a command is not valid if the leader does not say "command". If you make a mistake or are too late, you get a penalty point. Who will be the last man standing?

The simple rules ensure that everyone can participate directly.

Commando Pinkelen is based on a public domain game with the same name.

All those carrots look so tempting that you might just snatch them – but what if the wolves have been expecting exactly that, a greedy rabbit just like you? You never know...

In Om Nom Nom, during the game you will roll dice, which will represent various kinds of prey. By clever play of your hunter cards, you will try to eat the prey and thus gain victory points. At the end of the game the winner will be the player with the most points.

The game consists of 3 rounds. Each round is divided into 4 phases – roll, play, score and cleanup. During the "Roll" phase one of the players rolls all the dice. After rolling the dice are arranged on the game boards. During the "Play" phase all players will play all 6 of their predator cards one by one. When everyone has selected their first card, they are revealed simultaneously. This is where the action happens. Did You manage to guess what everyone else will play? Were You the only one brave enough to sneak Your mouse after the cheese? Or did You like everyone else play the wolf, because no rabbit surely could resist that amount of carrots. During this phase, players resolve all their played cards by capturing dice and cards of other players. During the "Score" phase players score points for captured cards and dice. And during the "Cleanup", when all 6 cards have been played, players gather all their cards back in hand and a new round can begin. At the end of the third round, player with the most points is the winner.

item.description:
It is the year 2025 and the entire world has fallen under the reign of a group of super villains known only as "The Collective". People are oppressed and the world has fallen deep into darkness with little hope of even a glimpse of light. In this dark world, a group of superheroes has risen to combat the villains and retake the world from their grasp.

Each mission is deadly, as both villains and superheroes must enter combat, defend themselves, and collect the previous element "levinium" or face destruction. Levinium is the heroes's hope of taking down the villains.

Reign of Evil is a print-and-play game in the genre of superheroes and supervillians. The game uses a card mechanic, and no dice, in order to perform combat. It plays quickly with minimal down time for players. Players move figures around the board to collect levinium until all wound markers are exhausted, until the deck runs out, or all levinium pieces are gone. Alternatively, players can play timed games. On their turns, players draw a hand of cards that contain a mix of Move and Action cards. Using these cards, players move around the board and take various actions, such as combat or collecting levinium.
A Space Invaders-themed Jenga set with a new type of game play. As you remove blocks you're also trying to move your Invader down the tower, so you can kill the puny humans.

item.description:
Caesar campaign's in Britannia: 55 & 54BC

THE GAME PLAY

To win, Caesar has to score points. He gains points when:
- He explores unknown regions
- He submits British tribes
- He returns in Gaul with his legions British hostages and booty

To win the Celtic has to prevent Caesar from marking points.

The first expedition lasts one month and Caesar has only two legions. It's very difficult for him to disembark.
The second expedition lasts two months. Caesar has 5 legions and the famous Gallic cavalry.

Actions in the game
A player takes an action with a chief, and then the other player takes an action too.
- Move
- Recruit (only for the Tribes, random units)
- Ravage (only for the Romans)
- Play a Stratagem (special real historical action)
- Reinforcement
- submit a tribe (for the roman player)
- Caesar special actions

Bounty
- it can boost recruitment and reinforcement
- you gain it with battle victory and ravage

Battle
- 4 tactical choices (units in first line can make critical hit but are the first to die)
- the best general has rerolls
- fire phase
- 2 melee phases

Specials
- Chariot actions: flee, dismount, special attack...
- bretons counters are hidden (not the number but the unity)

Available with French rules, but English rules can be downloaded from Vae Victis website.

item.description:
In Slaughterama, you are a vigilante hero who sets out to rid the land of evil, while also acting as clerk of your very own medieval store called a Bazaar. Traverse a unique board made up of tiles and fight a variety of demented foes. Once defeated, rob them of their treasures and use them to buy weapons and magic at opponent’s shops. There are also traps to avoid, the risk of becoming a zombie, snipers to watch out for, & magic portals that open up as the game progresses. This is a multi-player game, in fact, the more people playing...the more insane it becomes!

Slaughterama is a new, innovative table top game that is easy to learn yet quite challenging to win. There’s a good balance between luck and strategy, and the gameplay is fun NOT frustrating. With a variety of game mechanics at work, Slaughterama offers an engaging experience that is unlike anything else on the market today.

Amount of Players: 4 players (more by adding future deckpacks)

Object: Kill all 10 of the monsters in your deck before your opponents kill the ones in theirs.

Setting: A “medievalish” alternate universe where anarchy & chaos go for breakfast.

Duration: Customizable. A normal 4 player game on average takes about 90 minutes.

Game Mechanics: Dice rolling, pawn moving, simple RPG fighting system, card playing, buying/selling goods.

Rawen's land has been a place of war for hundreds of years. Twelve empires, twelve powerful gods — all longing for the same thing: limitless might.

Everything started with a Cataclysm and the appearance of the New Ones, who ruthlessly squelched the Old Ones — except for those who escaped into other planes of existence, specifically four parts of the world that managed to survive the catastrophe: the Big Continent, also known as Askalar where most of the empires lay; to the North, Iceland, the Isle of the Mages; in the south, Fireland, the home of Demons; and in Oceania, Bale, the Life Tree's territory.

The fight has not ended after the New Ones victory. The balance of forces varies, and it takes only a little to break the fragile balance. Fellowships are made, then breached in moments, but the stakes are much bigger than the power over Rawen. The New Ones fight not just for victory; they are seeking themselves. A secret part of their essence, which they can hardly remember. They were born on another world, which they gave up in exchange for survival. In the depths of their minds, a name pulsates about which neither their new dependents nor The Old Ones might know: Earth. The War of the Gods started in the far past of Rawen, but it affects the future of the whole universe.

In the Rawen Trading Card Game, the Gods of Rawen wield their power through their Warlords. As they expand their territories, the armies of the opposing Gods frequently battle one another. Your goal is to defeat the enemy warlord with the help of fighting units, heroes, and summoned spells. Successful attacks by your army weaken your enemies, and thus weaken their God, too. If the enemy warlord ever has as many wounds as health points, the warlord dies and you win the battle.

In game terms, each player chooses a warlord and a class, then creates a deck of at least 45 cards, with the warlord card, class card and primeval energy cards not counting toward this total. The game is turn-based, and in the main phase of your turn, you may act in any order, placing cards from your hand onto the battlefield, attacking with your units, activating a special power, and so on.

The goal is to build long marble tracks. On your turn you can move and/or rotate (Cuboro) elements. So that your marble track ends on an empty exit. You score points by the length (used Cuboro elements) of your track. The game is based on the cuboro system. There are different versions included. With the easy one you use only one level of the elements (on top). In the more challinging version you use tunnels as well.

item.description:
The young magicians are back in Der geheimnisvolle Spiegel (The Mysterious Mirror), exploring a house and seeing what they can find when they look in the mirror. Even better, they want to get their fellow magicians to guess the shapes of what they draw in the mirror!

To set up, players each take a magician tile and slide it into the bottom of one of the tile ladders; they also shuffle the 46 "magic symbol" tiles, each of which shows a line drawing of a familiar item, e.g., candle, butterfly, arrow, spider's web, etc.

The starting player draws a tile, takes the magic wand, and "draws" the image seen on this tile onto the back of the large "mysterious mirror" with the light of the wand. The other players try to guess the image drawn; the first player to do so gets to draw with the wand next, while the previous drawer places that tile into the bottom of her tile ladder. Players keep taking turns this way until someone pops her magician tile out of the top of the ladder, winning the game.

With two players, Der geheimnisvolle Spiegel is a co-operative game, with players taking turns drawing an image that the other player must guess. If a player draws three times and her fellow magician still can't guess, then the tile is placed into a third tile ladder. If this ladder fills before one of the magician's ladders, then they both lose the game.

Yu-Gi-Oh! Dice Masters is a dice-building game patterned after Quarriors! that features custom dice representing various characters from the 4K Media show.

In the game, each player brings a set of dice to the table; these form his team, from which only he can purchase dice. In addition, each player brings two basic action cards, which are placed in the center of the table; both players can purchase them.

During a turn, a player draws and rolls a number of his dice, purchases additional dice, and fields character dice to attack the other player. A player wins once the opposing player has been reduced to zero life.

Yu-Gi-Oh! Dice Masters is one of several planned Dice Masters games, all of which can be intermixed (or played alone).
